title: No, NASA didn't spend more than $165 million on an alien pen while the Russians used pencils.
text: A long-term online legend mocks the amount of time and money spent by NASA and Congress to develop an alien pen that can be written at zero gravity and maximum temperature because the Russians simply "used a pencil." The article says: "When NASA started sending astronauts, they quickly discovered that the ballpoint pens would not work at zero gravity. To combat this problem, Congress approved a program and NASA scientists spent a decade and over $165 million developing a pen that writes at zero gravity, upside down, on almost any surface and at temperatures ranging from less than freezing to more than 300 Celsius. The Russians used your tax pencil back in April. While the prosecution presents a good story, it has been dismantled several times. According to NASA, both American astronauts and Soviet astronauts used pencils in their first space missions. In fact, NASA requested 34 mechanical pens from Houston Camera Engineering for the Gemini Project, the second human space flight programme in 1965 and 1966. However, none of these funds came from NASA or Congress, according to multiple sources, including NASA and Fisher, now called Fisher Space Penn. In 1965, Fisher obtained the patent for the space pen, which used a compressed ink cartridge and could be written upside down, underwater, in other liquids and at maximum temperatures ranging from minus 50 degrees F to 400 degrees F. Because of the earlier controversy, however, NASA reports in its own account that it was "hesitating in its approach." After a series of tests, NASA managers agreed to equip astronauts with an anti-gravity Fisher pen, and in 1967, the Space Agency purchased about 400 pens at $6 per unit. In 1969, the Soviet Union also purchased 100 Fisher pens and 1,000 ink cartridges for use on its Soyuz space flight. In the 50 years that followed, both American astronauts and Soviet/Russian astronauts continued to use Fisher pens. Our ancient legend that NASA and Congress spent more than $165 million to develop the space pen while the Russians simply used pencils. At first, both space programmes used pencils.
